subject: Re: [junit] use of setUp and tearDown
msgSnippet: ... No, you should have one test failing; this test wouldn t have that setUp method (ie, it belongs to a different test class) and it would check the
messageBody:
> I am not sure this is the real output: setUp is an ERROR
> so i should see: 101 TESTS, 101 RAN, 1 ERROR, 100 FAILURES

No, you should have one test failing; this test wouldn't
have that setUp method (ie, it belongs to a different test
class) and it would check the precondition that the failing
setUp() depends on. This test would fail. That's 1 failure.

The setUp() method for the other 100 tests throws
exceptions. These aren't expected, so they are errors.
That's 100 errors. So, you get:

101 TESTS, 101 RAN, 1 FAILURE, 100 ERRORS

Of course, to get this you need:
1) A test runner that will report in this format. :) Most
don't, but they will give equivalent information.
2) Test structures setup accordingly - you need to have that
test outside of the first test case that will fail rather
than error.
